Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: NSF/DOE Thermoelectric Partnership: High-Performance Thermoelectric Devices Based on Abundant Silicide Materials for Vehicle Waste Heat Recovery

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1048767

Shi

This project seeks to develop novel thermoelectric materials for use in prototype thermoelectric modules to promote the cost-effective conversion of waste heat in vehicle exhaust systems.

Intellectual Merit: This proposal addresses four elements that are critical for successful implementation of thermoelectric devices for waste heat recovery from vehicle exhaust. These include development of new thermoelectric materials, system-level modeling, heat sink development, and reduction of thermal and electric resistances at material-material interfaces. The thermoelectric materials of interest are silicides, in which the lattice thermal conductivity of both the p- and n-type material will be reduced through nanostructuring, hence increasing the efficacy with which the material will perform in waste heat recovery scenarios. Once developed, the new material will be incorporated into thermoelectric modules, and the modules will be installed on a 6.7 liter diesel engine to measure system performance under realistic operating conditions. A system-level model will be developed and utilized to identify opportunities to further increase and optimize the overall design. Material properties will be measured at the PIs institutions as well as at Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

Broader Impact: The successful development and implementation of new thermoelectric materials and module designs will improve fuel economy and reduce emissions. Graduate students will be involved in the research. Video course modules specific to thermoelectric waste heat recovery will be developed and disseminated via the Internet for K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students. Outreach to a broad segment of the local population will be conducted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solid-state thermoelectric power generation devices can convert heat directly into electricity with few mechanical moving parts. They have attracted renewed interest due to the increasing global need for energy and negative environmental consequence of fossil fuels. For the past decades, many material systems such as lead telluride, skutterudites and silicon germanium have been studied for thermoelectric energy conversion. However, most of these state-of-art thermoelectric materials contain toxic or relatively costly elements.

The overall goal of this project is to address several critical fundamental and applied challenges associated with performance, cost, and scalability of thermoelectric devices for vehicle waste heat recovery. The research is focused on thermoelectric materials based on some silicides, which are made of nontoxic elements that are abundant in the earth’s crust. Higher manganese silicides (HMS) and magnesium silicides based materials have been synthesized as p-type and n-type legs of thermoelectric power generation modules, respectively. X-ray diffraction, inelastic neutron scattering, and thermal and electrical transport measurements have been employed to develop a better understanding of structure-thermoelectric property relationship for these silicides materials. The thermoelectric properties of these silicides have been improved by chemical doping and nanostructuring. One important finding of this research is the discovery of low-energy phonons associated with twisting motions of the Si ladders inside the Mn chimneys in HMS crystals, as shown in the attached figure. Such twisting phonons play an important role in the intrinsically low thermal conductivity of HMS. Furthermore, thermoelectric devices have been fabricated using HMS and magnesium silicide based materials. A high fidelity finite difference model has been developed to study the interdependencies among the optimization parameters for thermoelectric elements integrated with an exhaust gas heat exchanger.

The fundamental research consists of a number of new approaches that can impact the performance, cost, and scalability of TE devices for vehicle waste heat recovery. A better understanding of the structure-property relationship of complex silicide materials and the effects of doping and nanostructuring have laid the foundation for increasing the thermoelectric energy conversion performance of these low-cost materials to a level needed for cost-efficient vehicle waste heat recovery at a scale commensurate to the global vehicle manufacturing enterprise. The established device- and system- level computation tool can address the current need of an adequate design tool for optimizing heat transfer and conversion efficiency in thermoelectric waste heat recovery systems. In addition, the research findings have been disseminated to the research community in journal articles, book chapters, conference proceeding papers, and invited presentations in technical conferences and departmental seminars of different universities.

The research has provided interdisciplinary education and international collaboration opportunities for seven graduate students, including two female graduate students. Thanks to the NSF support, two graduate students have completed a Ph.D. degree, two graduate students have completed a M.S. degree, and the two female graduate students are scheduled to defend their Ph.D. dissertation this year. Furthermore, we have positively impacted human resource development through hands-on experimental demonstrations to a broad community including K-12 students during annual university-wide outreach events as well as the South by the Southwest Music and Media Conference and Festival hosted by the city of Austin.
